Colonies consist of a series of hard, solid and well calcified, brittle, interconnected plates that are usually yellow, orange or red and are often bristling with spines and avicularia, giving them a furry appearance.

Two difficult to distinguish species occur in the Western Cape â€“ C. capensis and C. septispina and these are dealt with as a group here.  (A third species, C. atypica, occurs in the Eastern Cape but, as indicated by the name, has an atypical, encrusting colony form and is found on mussel shells).

When viewed closely the individual zooecia are more or less diamond-shaped and irregularly arranged.
Individual zooecia less then 1 mm long, colonies up to 20 cm across.

Global: Both species endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Chaperia capensis Cape Peninsula to East London, C. septispina known only from False Bay.

Form upright folded colonies on rocky substrata in gullies and the sides of deep rock pools and on reefs to a depth of about 100 m. Often mingled with other sedentary invertebrates, such as sponges, other bryozoans and soft corals. Very little other species-specific information available.

All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
Colonies expand by budding new zooecia around the margins. New colonies formed by sexual reproduction, fertilized eggs being released into the water column to disperse and establish new colonies.

Chaperiopsis multifida forms similar brittle, calcified and folded colonies, but is maroon in colour and the zooecia have a pair of characteristic antler-like spines that obscure much of the front surface of each zooid. Several other genera form similar plates, but which are punctured by regularly-spaced holes rather than being solid.

Boonzaaier-Davids, MK, Ma, KC & Mcquaid, CD (2023). Epibiotic association of encrusting cheilostome bryozoans on shells of an invasive mussel from rocky shores of South Africa, with the description of a new aviculiferous species of Chaperia. Zootaxa, 5258(2), 197-210.
